results.title: Possessions
results.creator_credit: Michael Dibb and TAFE National Video Resource Centre (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Ways of seeing”.
One of a series of films by art critic and author John Berger, which explores the ways in which we look at pictures. John Berger believes we have misunderstood the real meaning of European oil painting because we are normally encouraged to look at only a few exceptional works instead of the hundreds of thousands of unremakable pictures which make up the main tradition. He argues that this still continues today in the modern medium of advertising and publicity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Dibb and TAFE National Video Resource Centre (Australia)

results.title: Possessions (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Ways of seeing”.
One of a series of films by the distinguished art critic and author, John Berger, in which he explores the ways in which we look at pictures. Berger argues that paintings were, and still are, the most valuable single objects which we can possess.

results.title: Nude or naked?
results.creator_credit: Michael Dibb and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Ways of seeing”.
One of a series of films by art critic and author John Berger which explores the ways in which we look at pictures. He looks at oil paintings over the last 400 years of the nude and interprets painting as being made for a male audience. He asks whether there is a difference between being naked or nude. How do European oil paintings of nudes compare with the images of modern advertisements? Finally, he asks women for their comments on how men see them or have seen them in the past and on how this influences the way women see themselves. Attempts to explain the difference between nudity and nakedness in art. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Reproductions
results.creator_credit: Michael Dibb and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Ways of seeing”.
John Berger, art critic and author explores the ways in which we look at pictures particularly the way paintings are now most frequently seen; reproduced in the form of postcards, books, television and films. Illustrates how the images of art can be manipulated and demonstrates how they can be obscured by the false religiosity and mystification so often surrounding them.

results.title: The Global Economy
results.creator_credit: Monash University, Open Learning Agency of Australia and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: An Open Learning University video course in Economics. This series examines some of the questions concerning contemporary students of Economics and International Relations. Each episode incorporates a round-table panel discussion by international economists who discuss the issues and themes introduced.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Monash University, Open Learning Agency of Australia and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: The Evolving world (NP)
results.creator_credit: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, Open Learning Agency of Australia, Monash University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “The Global Economy”.
This episode of The Global Economy focuses on the changing nature of the world’s various economies by considering two examples: China as a developing economy (Passing on development) and the USA (Continual change, continual growth) with its dominance of the computer software industry. A panel of economists discuss the nature of change in the local market place and the effects this creates globally.

results.title: The Environment (NP)
results.creator_credit: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, Open Learning Agency of Australia, Monash University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “The Global Economy”.
This episode of the Open Learning Economics course looks at the way the international economic community is tackling the issue of environmental protection. Since the late 1970s there has been a growing concern, especially by communities in wealthier nations, over the high environmental cost of unrestricted economic development. Developing countries, however, have argued that trade restrictions predicated on environmental law offer unfair economic advantages to richer nations. In the first half of the program we look at the example of the Mexican tuna industry which has come under fire because of the destruction of dolphin life. However when the United States attempted to place an embargo on Mexican tuna, the General Agreement on Tarrifs and Trade (GATT) ruled that this was contrary to the principles of Free Trade. In the second half we look at the destruction of Europe’s Rhine River by industrial pollution. The panel of economists examining both issues discuss some of the implications for trade if environmental law becomes institutionalised in the global economy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, Open Learning Agency of Australia, Monash University and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Economies in transition (NP)
results.creator_credit: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, Open Learning Agency of Australia, Monash University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “The Global Economy”.
This episode of the Open Learning Economics course examines the development of free market economic systems in the former communist states of Eastern Europe. The first episode looks at the emergence of liberal capitalism in Russia. The episode examines the benefits of opening Russia’s markets to the rest of the globe though it acknowledges that this embracement of capitalism, at an accelerated pace, has the potential to create devastating divisions based on wealth. The second episode looks at the success of capitalism in Poland which turned away from State Socialism in the early 1980s. In interviews with economists and Polish business people we are given an insight into some of the difficulties involved in dismantling a socialist economic system and replacing it with a market open to the international capitalist economy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, Open Learning Agency of Australia, Monash University and ABC-TV (Australia)
